<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 322, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 366, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
1 The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents the sequence of two transformations in the \(x-y\) plane given by a stretch parallel to the \(x\)-axis, scale factor 14 , followed by a rotation anticlockwise about the origin through angle \(\frac{1}{3} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 120, 144, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 109, 411, 144]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(2 \mathbf{M}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}14 & -\sqrt{ } 3 \\ 14 \sqrt{ } 3 & 1\end{array}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 459, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x-y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{M}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 616, 709, 632]]<|/det|>
<pre>The unit square \(S\) in the \(x-y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto the rectangle \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 647, 144, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 644, 497, 662]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the matrix which transforms \(P\) onto \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
2 Prove by mathematical induction that \(2025^{n}+47^{n}-2\) is divisible by 46 for all positive integers \(n\) ．［6］

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 72, 562, 85]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 618, 97]]<|/det|>
3 The quartic equation \(x^{4}+7 x^{2}+3 x+22=0\) has roots \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 108, 440, 127]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}+\gamma^{2}+\delta^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 572, 144, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 570, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}+\gamma^{4}+\delta^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 730, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to find the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 95, 688, 135]]<|/det|>
\[
\sum_{r=1}^{10}\left(\left(\alpha^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\beta^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\gamma^{2}+r\right)^{2}+\left(\delta^{2}+r\right)^{2}\right)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 789, 95]]<|/det|>
(c) Given that \(v_{r}=x^{w_{r+1}}-x^{w_{r}}\), find the set of values of \(x\) for which the infinite series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 106, 566, 127]]<|/det|>
\[
v_{1}+v_{2}+v_{3}+\ldots
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 138, 616, 157]]<|/det|>
is convergent and give the sum to infinity when this exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 700, 95]]<|/det|>
5 The plane \(\Pi\) has equation \(\mathbf{r}=2 \mathbf{i}+3 \mathbf{j}-2 \mathbf{k}+\lambda(\mathbf{i}-2 \mathbf{j}-\mathbf{k})+\mu(3 \mathbf{i}+2 \mathbf{j}-2 \mathbf{k})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 108, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 107, 785, 125]]<|/det|>
(a) Find a Cartesian equation of \(\Pi\), giving your answer in the form \(a x+b y+c z=d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 508, 466, 526]]<|/det|>
<pre>The point \(P\) has position vector \(4 \mathbf{i}+2 \mathbf{j}+9 \mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 540, 144, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 539, 694, 556]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the position vector of the foot of the perpendicular from \(P\) to \(\Pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 429, 144, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 428, 505, 446]]<|/det|>
(c) The line \(l\) is parallel to the vector \(3 \mathbf{i}+5 \mathbf{j}-\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 459, 454, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(l\) and \(\Pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 84, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 653, 107]]<|/det|>
6 The curve \(C\) has equation \(y=\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 117, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 115, 489, 133]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 551, 144, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 548, 676, 567]]<|/det|>
(b) Find, in terms of \(a\), the \(x\)-coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 682, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 508, 144, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 495, 504, 530]]<|/det|>
(d) Sketch the curve with equation \(y=\left|\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 85, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 717, 107]]<|/det|>
(e) Find the set of values of \(a\) for which \(\left|\frac{x^{2}+a}{x+a}\right|=a\) has two real solutions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 72, 562, 85]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 648, 98]]<|/det|>
7 The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r^{2}=\mathrm{e}^{\sin \theta} \cos \theta\), for \(-\frac{1}{2} \pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 109, 918, 141]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the pole, giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 528, 144, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 523, 918, 560]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the polar coordinates of the point on \(C\) that is furthest from the half-line \(\theta=\frac{1}{2} \pi\), giving your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 235, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 508, 144, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 507, 749, 524]]<|/det|>
(d) Find the area of the region bounded by \(C\), giving your answer in exact form.
